column4: Hi.  Scripts in /etc/init.d are run at bootup, right?  It seems some of them aren't starting for me: dnsmasq, tor, polipo, etc.  How can I troubleshoot this?  thanks
check "service'
it's upstart which is resposible for running those scripts.
thanks, but I'm not sure what I need to do.  Does this mean that /etc/init.d/ aren't started, or that old Sys V and Upstart coexist?
it means that you need to configure upstart to actually start your services
maco: I see.  Actually a lot of them aren't symlinks, and they seem to be the ones that aren't working: dnsmasq, tor, polipo, vboxdrv, hddtemp...  How do I configure upstart with them?
maco: should I just symlink from /lib/init ?
probably not. look at /etc/rc*.d/
there is also a program called rc-update or the like. You mihgt be interested in looking at that.
All the services that aren't starting are already linked in /etc/rc2.d/ : tor, polipo, dnsmasq, hddtemp and vboxdrv
nice. now go and figure out what runlevels are and how sysvinit starts services based on the runlevel.

I see.  Just read the Wikipedia art. re: runlevels and a linux.com art. re: Upstart and runleveles.  Ubuntu emulates runlevels using Upstart.  But still, I don't know how to make the services start on boot.
maco: can you please help me any further?
try symlinking /etc/init.d/tor to /etc/rc1.d/S10tor  or the like.
no, in rcS.d/ I guess.
but you better check sysvinit/upstart documentatino on that.
rcS.d is for single-user mode
uh, hm. sorry, but apparently you know what you are talking about :-) Maybe it's rc5.d..
thanks, but rc5.d seems to be for X11 apps: https://secure.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/wiki/Runlevel#Typical_Linux_runlevels
rc4.d?
I'm sorry. I don't know. But you can check your current runlevel with telinit or so I think. That might help you
No worries.   Thank you
